Understate: The claim understates the frequency of snowy owl sightings in Central Park by implying that it has not been seen in over a century, when in fact there have been previous sightings in 1890 and 1993.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to definitively state that this is the first spotting of a snowy owl in Central Park in over 130 years, as there have been previous sightings recorded.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the snowy owl spotted in Central Park in January 2021 is the first sighting in over a century, without considering alternative explanations or the possibility of unrecorded sightings.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the presence of the snowy owl in Central Park, such as a scarcity of their accustomed food or following the migration patterns of other bird species.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that a snowy owl was also seen in Central Park on March 6, 1993, which challenges the assertion that this is the first sighting in over a century.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the snowy owl sighting by stating that it created a "flurry of excitement" on social media, implying a greater level of public interest and attention than may have actually occurred.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing consistent and accurate information about the history of snowy owl sightings in Central Park.
